div1.p: Legation de Belgique Washington 25 Nov. 04

Monsieur le Chevalier
Son formément au désir que vous avez bien voulu m'exprimer par votre cable du 19 de ce mois, je me suis rendu au département d'Etat pour demander s'il entrenait dans les vues du gouvernement amé- ricain de conclure avec l'Etat Independant du Congo une convention d'arbitrage.

Je n'ai pas pu voir M. May qui était absent, mais je me suis entretenu avec le Sous Secrétaire d'Etat et lui ai indiqué, d'après votre telegramme basé sur lesquelles l'arrangement dont il s'agit pour- rait être fait.
M. Loomis a rendu compte, ce matin, de notre
Monsieur le Chevalier de Guvelier Secrétaire General des Affaires Etrangeres en l'Etat Independant du Congo
conversation à M May, il m'envoie la communica- tion suivante que je copie tentuellement: (Personal)- Nov. 25. 04

"Dear Baron, regerring to our conversation yesterday, Mr May thinks it would not be advisable at this time to depart from his practice of negotiating uniform treaties with powers which were parties to the convention- (As the Congo Free State was not a party to that convention he thinks an arbitration treaty with it could not be negotiated in the present instance, but the matter might possi- bly be taken up at some future time on a somewhat different basis from the treaties now being negociated- very sincerely yours (s) Loomis
Les informations sont conformes à ce que m'avait dit dernierement M May a propos du projet Belge- Il désire que toutes les conventions

d'arbitrage conclus avec les Puissants adhérentes à l'Acte de la Haye soit uniformes, de manière à pouvoir être, le mois prochain, présentées en bloc à la ratification du Senat- le type uni- forme est, comme vous le savez, la convention Anglo-Francaise.
Comme le dit Son Excellence on pourra ensuite traiter avec l'Etat du Congo sur une base quelque peu differente.

J'avais tardé plusieurs jours avant de m'adresser au Departement d'Etat espérant recevoir préalablement le projet Belge du conven- tion d'arbitrage auquel se réfère votre telegramme et que la Département des Affaires Etrangeres à Bruxelles m'annonce depuis un certain temps déjà- mais le courrier d'Europe était arrivé sans m'apporter ce document, je n'ai pas
retader d'avantage ma démarche.
Veuillez agréer, Monsieur le Chevalier, les assurances de ma très haute consideration
Legation of Belgium Washington 25 Nov. 04

Mister Knight
Conforming to the desire that you wanted to express to me by your cable from the 19th of this month, I rendered myself to the Department of State to ask if it maintained in the views of the american govern- ment to conclude with the Independent State of the Congo a convention of arbitration.
I could not see Mr. May who was absent, but I spoke with the Under Secretary of State and indicated to him, according to your telegram based on those which the arrangement in question could be made.
Mr. Loomis reported, this morning, our
Mister Knight of Guvelier Secretary General of Foreign Affairs in the Independent State of the Congo
conversation to Mr May, he sends to me the following communication that I copy word for word: (Personal)- Nov. 25. 04

"Dear Baron, regerring to our conversation yesterday, Mr May thinks it would not be advisable at this time to depart from his practice of negotiating uniform treaties with powers which were parties to the convention- (As the Congo Free State was not a party to that convention he thinks an arbitration treaty with it could not be negotiated in the present instance, but the matter might possi- bly be taken up at some future time on a somewhat different basis from the treaties now being negociated- very sincerely yours (s) Loomis
The information is conformed to that which was said to me lastly about Mr May about the Belgian project- He desires that all the conventions

of arbitration conclude with the Powers adhering to the Act of the Hague be uniform, in such a way to be able to be, next month, presented entirely to the ratification of the Senate- the uniform type is, as you know, the Anglo-French convention.
As the said His Excellence one can then negotiate with the State of the Congo on a somewhat different base.

I had waited several days before addressing myself to the Department of State hoping to receive beforehand the Belgian project of the conven- tion of arbitration which was referred to in your telegram and that the Department of Foreign Affairs in Brussels has announced to me for a certain time already- but the mail in Europe had arrived without bringing me this document, I did not
delay any longer my process.
Please accept, Mister Knight, the assurances of my highest consideration
